meanings.definition: To withdraw or retract a statement or action.
meanings.sent1: I had to retrack my words after realizing I was mistaken.
meanings.sent2: She decided to retrack her promise to help, causing disappointment.
meanings.sent3: He had to retrack his joke when he saw it upset his friend.
meanings.sent4: The politician had to retrack his bold claim after it was proven false.
meanings.sent5: It's important to retrack any false information to maintain credibility.

meanings.definition: To go back over a path or route.
meanings.sent1: We had to retrack our steps to find the lost keys.
meanings.sent2: The hikers needed to retrack their trail to reach the campsite.
meanings.sent3: The detective had to retrack the suspect's movements to solve the case.
meanings.sent4: She had to retrack her route after taking a wrong turn.
meanings.sent5: It's helpful to retrack your path if you get lost in the woods.

meanings.definition: To pull back or draw in.
meanings.sent1: The turtle can retrack its head into its shell for protection.
meanings.sent2: She quickly learned to retrack her hand when the puppy tried to bite.
meanings.sent3: The curtains can retrack easily with a gentle tug.
meanings.sent4: He had to retrack the fishing line to reel in the big catch.
meanings.sent5: It's fascinating to watch a cat retrack its claws when playing.
